{{slavery}} The issue of '''[[slavery]]''' and '''[[religion]]''' is an area of historical research into the relationship between the world's major religions and the practice of slavery. Slavery could be a result of being a prisoner of war, owing a debt or being sold into slavery. Historically slavery has been supported by several major religions. A passage in the [[Bible]] has historically been interpreted by a subset of [[Christian]]s to mean that anyone with dark (black) skin also had a black soul, condemning them to slavery. Some Christians also enslaved non-believers as the "natural order of things" and saw any non-believer as a potential slave. Enslaved non-believers were sometimes converted to Christianity but elements of their traditional beliefs merged with their Christian beliefs. Some Popes since the 15th century denounced slavery, and various denominations were for or against slavery into the 19th century. In Judaism, slaves were given a range of treatments and protections. They were to be treated as extended family with certain protections and could be freed. They were property but could also own material goods. In Islam, under [[Sharia]] law, prisoners of war could be enslaved. Hindus encourage liberation as an ultimate goal, and their scriptures do not discuss slavery. However, [[Sanskrit]] language [[Hindu]] texts such as the ''[[Arthashastra]]'', and the [[Pali]] language [[Buddhist]] texts, contain the word ''dasa'', which is translated as either "servant" or "slave".
== Slavery in the Bible ==
{{main|The Bible and slavery}}
[[Book of Genesis|Genesis]] narrative about the [[Curse of Ham]] has often been held to be an [[aetiology|aetiological]] story, giving a reason for the enslavement of the [[Canaanites]]. The word ''ham'' is very similar to the [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] word for ''hot'', which is [[cognate]] with an [[Egyptian language|Egyptian]] word (''kem'', meaning ''[[black (hieroglyphic 'km')|black]]'') used to refer to [[Ancient Egypt|Egypt]] itself, in reference to the fertile black soil along the [[Nile valley]]. Although many scholars therefore view ''Ham'' as an eponym used to represent Egypt in the [[Table of Nations]],<ref>''Jewish Encyclopedia'' (1901), article on ''Ham''</ref> a number of Christians throughout history, including [[Origen]]<ref>Origen, ''Homilies'', on Genesis 16:1</ref> and the [[Cave of Treasures]],<ref>(edited by Ciala Kourcikidzé), ''The cave of treasures: Georgian version'', translated by [[Jean-Pierre Mahé]] in ''The written corpus of eastern Christianity'' 526-27, part of ''Scriptores Iberici'' 23-24 (Louvain, 1992-93), 21:38-39</ref> have argued for the alternate proposition that ''Ham'' represents all [[black people]], his name symbolising their dark skin colour;<ref>Goldenberg, D. M. (2003). The Curse of Ham. Princeton, New Jersey: Princeton University Press, page 141.</ref> pro-slavery advocates, from [[Patriarch Eutychius of Alexandria|Eutychius of Alexandria]]<ref>(edited by J.P. Migne), ''Complete course in Patrology…Greek series'', (Paris, 1857-66), on ''Annals'' 111:917B:41-43</ref> and [[John Philoponus]],<ref>A. Sanda, ''Opposcula Monophysitica Johannes Philoponi'' (Beirut, 1930), page 96</ref> to American pro-slavery apologists,<ref>Haynes, S. R. (2002). Noah's Curse. New York: Oxford University Press, page 71.</ref> have therefore occasionally interpreted the narrative as a condemnation of all black people to slavery.<ref>Felder, C. H. (2002). Race, Racism, and the Biblical Narratives. Minneapolis, Minnesota: Augsburg Fortress, page 8.</ref> A few Christians, like [[Jerome]], even took up the [[racism|racist notion]] that black people inherently had ''a soul as black as [their] body''.<ref>Jerome, ''Homilies'', 1:3:28</ref>
Slavery was customary in [[Ancient history|antiquity]], and it is condoned by the [[Torah]].<ref>{{bibleverse||Exodus|22:2-3|}}</ref> The Bible uses the [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] term ''ebed'' to refer to slavery; however, ''ebed'' has a much wider meaning than the English term ''slavery'', and in several circumstances it is more accurately translated into English as ''servant''.<ref>''[[Jewish Encyclopedia]]'' (1901), article on ''Slaves and Slavery''</ref> It was seen as legitimate to enslave captives obtained through warfare,<ref>{{bibleverse||Deuteronomy|20:10-16|}}</ref> but not through kidnapping.<ref>{{bibleverse||Deuteronomy|24:7|}}</ref><ref>{{bibleverse||Exodus|20:10-16|}}</ref> Children could also be sold into [[debt bondage]],<ref>{{bibleverse||Leviticus|25:44|}}</ref> which was sometimes ordered by a court of law.<ref>{{bibleverse||Isaiah|22:2-3|}}</ref><ref>{{bibleverse|2|Kings|4:1-7|}}</ref><ref name="Jewish Encyclopedia 1901">''Jewish Encyclopedia'' (1901), article on ''Slaves and Slavery''</ref>
As with the [[Biblical Hittites|Hittite]] Laws and the [[Code of Hammurabi]],<ref>''Peake's commentary on the Bible'' (1962), on Exodus 21:18-27</ref> the Bible does set minimum rules for the conditions under which slaves were to be kept. Slaves were to be treated as part of an extended family;<ref name="bibleverse||Deuteronomy|16:14">{{bibleverse||Deuteronomy|16:14|}}</ref> they were allowed to celebrate the [[Sukkot]] festival,<ref name="bibleverse||Deuteronomy|16:14"/> and expected to honour [[Shabbat]].<ref>{{bibleverse||Exodus|20:10|}}</ref> Israelite slaves could not be compelled to work ''with rigour'',<ref>{{bibleverse||Leviticus|25:43|}}</ref><ref>{{bibleverse||Leviticus|25:53|}}</ref> and debtors who sold themselves as slaves to their creditors had to be treated the same as a hired servant.<ref>{{bibleverse||Leviticus|25:39|}}</ref> If a master harmed a slave in one of the ways covered by the [[lex talionis]], the slave was to be compensated by [[manumission]];<ref>{{bibleverse||Exodus|21:26-27|}}</ref> if the slave died within 24 to 48 hours, he or she was to be ''avenged''<ref>{{bibleverse||Exodus|21:20-21|}}</ref> (whether this refers to the [[death penalty]]<ref name="Jewish Encyclopedia 1901"/><ref name="Maimonides, Mishneh Torah">Maimonides, ''Mishneh Torah''</ref> or not<ref>''Jewish Encyclopedia'' (1901), article on ''Avenger of Blood''</ref> is uncertain).
Israelite slaves were automatically manumitted after six years of work, and/or at the next [[Jubilee (Biblical)|Jubilee]] (occurring either every 49 or every 50 years, depending on interpretation), although the latter would not apply if the slave was owned by an Israelite and wasn't in debt bondage.<ref>{{bibleverse||Leviticus|25:47-55|}}</ref> Slaves released automatically in their 7th year of service, which did not include female slaves,<ref>{{bibleverse||Exodus|21:7|}}</ref> or<ref>''Jewish Encyclopedia'' (1901), article on ''Law, Codification of''</ref><ref>''Peake's commentary on the Bible'' (1962), on Exodus 21:2-11</ref> did,<ref>{{bibleverse||Deuteronomy|15:12|}}</ref> were to be given livestock, grain, and wine, as a parting gift<ref>{{bibleverse||Deuteronomy|15:13-14|}}</ref> (possibly hung round their necks<ref name="Jewish Encyclopedia 1901"/>). This 7th-year manumission could be voluntarily renounced, which would be signified, as in other Ancient Near Eastern nations,<ref>[[Thomas Kelly Cheyne]] and John Sutherland Black, ''[[Encyclopaedia Biblica]]'' (1903), article on ''Slavery''</ref> by the slave gaining a ritual [[ear piercing]];<ref>{{bibleverse||Exodus|21:5-6|}}</ref> after such renunciation, the individual was enslaved ''forever'' (and not released at the Jubilee<ref>Thomas Kelly Cheyne and John Sutherland Black, ''Encyclopaedia Biblica'' (1903), article on ''Slavery''</ref>). Non-Israelite slaves were always to be enslaved ''forever'', and treated as inheritable property.<ref>{{bibleverse||Leviticus|25:44-46|}}</ref>
In several [[Pauline epistles]], and the [[First Epistle of Peter]], slaves are admonished to obey their masters, ''as to the Lord, and not to men'';<ref>{{bibleverse||Ephesians|6:5-8|}}</ref><ref>{{bibleverse||Colossians|3:22-25|}}</ref><ref>{{bibleverse|1|Timothy|6:1|}}</ref><ref>{{bibleverse||Titus|2:9-10|}}</ref><ref>{{bibleverse|1|Peter|2:18}}</ref> however these particular ''Pauline epistles'' are also [[authorship of the Pauline epistles|those whose Pauline authorship is doubted]] by many modern scholars.<ref>{{cite book |last=Ehrman |first=Bart D.|authorlink=Bart D. Ehrman |title=The New Testament: A Historical Introduction to the Early Christian Writings |year=2004 |publisher=Oxford |location=New York |isbn=0-19-515462-2 }}, page 385</ref><ref>[[Udo Schnelle]], ''Apostle Paul: His Life and Theology'' (2003), [english translation published 2005]</ref><ref>[[Hermann Detering]], ''The Falsified Paul'' (1995)</ref><ref>Stephen G. Wilson, ''Luke and the Pastoral Epistles'' (1979)</ref><ref>[[Norman Perrin]], ''The New Testament: An Introduction'' (1974)</ref><ref>W. Bujard, ''Stilanalytische Untersuchungen zum Kolosserfrief als Beitrag zur Methodik von Sprachvergleichen'' (1973)</ref><ref>E J Goodspeed, ''Key to Ephesians'' (1956), page 6</ref><ref>Mitton, ''The Epistle to the Ephesians'' (1951), pages 245-255</ref><ref>[[Alfred Loisy]], ''The Origins of the New Testament'' (1936)</ref><ref>Percy Neale Harrison, ''The Problem of the Pastoral Epistles'' (1921)</ref><ref>[[Ferdinand Christian Baur]], ''Paul, the Apostle of Jesus Christ: His Life and Works'' (1845)</ref><ref>also partially advocated by [[Desiderius Erasmus]]</ref> By contrast, the [[First Epistle to the Corinthians]], one of the ''undisputed epistles'',<ref>Seven of the Pauline Epistles are regarded as genuine by most scholars; academics therefore use the term ''undisputed epistles'' to collectively refer to these seven</ref> describes lawfully obtained manumission as the ideal for slaves.<ref>{{bibleverse|1|Corinthians|7:21-23|}}</ref> Another ''undisputed epistle'' is [[Epistle to Philemon|that to Philemon]], which has become an important text in regard to slavery, being used by pro-slavery advocates as well as by abolitionists;<ref>Religion and the Antebellum Debate Over Slavery, by John R. McKivigan, Mitchell Snay</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://medicolegal.tripod.com/cheevergvs.htm#p140|title=God Against Slavery, p. 140, by Rev. George B. Cheever, D.D|author=Rev. George B. Cheever, D.D., in 1857|publisher=|accessdate=23 October 2014}}</ref> in the epistle, [[Paul of Tarsus|Paul]] returns Onesimus, a fugitive slave, back to his master nature, which was opposed to the equality in which mankind was created.<ref>Philo, ''On the contemplative life''</ref>
==Judaism== {{main|Jewish views on slavery}} More mainstream forms of first-century [[Judaism]] didn't exhibit such qualms about slavery, and ever since the 2nd-century expulsion of Jews from Judea, wealthy Jews have owned non-Jewish slaves, wherever it was legal to do so;<ref name="Jewish Encyclopedia 1901"/> nevertheless, manumissions were approved by Jewish religious officials on the slightest of pretexts, and court cases concerning manumission were nearly always decided in favour of freedom, whenever there was uncertainty towards the facts.<ref name="Maimonides, Mishneh Torah"/><ref>''[[minor tractate|The Minor Tractates]]'', ''Abadim'' 9:6</ref>
The [[Talmud]], a document of great importance in Judaism, made many rulings which had the effect of making manumission easier and more likely: *The costly and compulsory giving of gifts was restricted the 7th-year manumission only.<ref name="Jewish Encyclopedia 1901"/> *The price of freedom was reduced to a proportion of the original purchase price rather than the total fee of a hired servant, and could be reduced further if the slave had become weak or sickly (and therefore less saleable).<ref name="Jewish Encyclopedia 1901"/><ref name="Maimonides, Mishneh Torah"/> *Voluntary manumission became officially possible, with the introduction of the manumission deed (the ''shetar shihrur''), which was counted as [[prima facie]] proof of manumission. *Verbal declarations of manumission could no longer be revoked.<ref>''[[Gittin]]'' 1:6</ref> *Putting [[Tefillin|phylacteries]] on the slave, or making him publicly read three or more verses from the Torah, was counted as a declaration of the slave's manumission.<ref name="Maimonides, Mishneh Torah"/> *Extremely long term sickness, for up to four years in total, couldn't count against the slave's right to manumission after six years of enslavement.<ref name="Jewish Encyclopedia 1901"/><ref name="Maimonides, Mishneh Torah"/>
Jewish participation in the slave trade itself was also regulated by the Talmud. Fear of [[apostasy]] lead to the Talmudic discouragement of the sale of Jewish slaves to non-Jews,<ref>''Gittin'', 4:6</ref> although loans were allowed;<ref>''Gittin'', 46b</ref> similarly slave trade with [[Tyre, Lebanon|Tyre]] was only to be for the purpose of removing slaves from non-Jewish religion.<ref>''Jewish Encyclopedia'' (1901), article on ''Fairs''</ref> [[Religious racism]] meant that the Talmudic writers completely forbade the sale or transfer of [[Canaan]]ite slaves out from [[Roman Palestine|Palestine]] to elsewhere.<ref>''Gittin'' 4:6</ref> Other types of trade were also discouraged: men selling themselves to women, and post-[[puberty|pubescent]] daughters being sold into slavery by their fathers.<ref name="Jewish Encyclopedia 1901"/><ref name="Maimonides, Mishneh Torah"/> Pre-pubescent slave girls sold by their fathers had to be freed-then-married by their new owner, or his son, when she ''started'' [[puberty]];<ref name="Jewish Encyclopedia 1901"/> slaves could not be allowed to marry free Jews,<ref>''Gittin'' 4:5</ref> although masters were often granted access to the ''services'' of the wives of any of their slaves.<ref>''[[Nashim|Kiddushin]]'' 22a</ref>
According to the Talmudic law, killing of a slave is punishable in the same way as killing of a freeman, even if it was committed by the owner. While slaves are considered the owner's property, they may not work on Sabbath and holidays; they may acquire and hold property of the own.<ref>''Encyclopedia Judaica, 2007, vol. 18,'' p. 668</ref>
Several prominent Jewish writers of the Middle Ages took offense at the idea that Jews might be enslaved; [[Joseph Caro]] and [[Maimonides]] both argue that calling a Jew ''slave'' was so offensive that it should be punished by [[excommunication]].<ref>Maimonides, ''Mishneh Torah'', 6:14</ref><ref>Joseph Caro, ''[[Shulkhan Arukh]]'', ''Yoreah De'ah'' 334</ref> However, they did not condemn enslavement of non-Jews. Indeed, they argued that the biblical rule, that slaves should be freed for certain injuries, should actually only apply to slaves who had converted to Judaism;<ref name="Jewish Encyclopedia 1901"/> additionally, Maimonides argued that this manumission was really punishment of the owner, and therefore it could only be imposed by a court, and required evidence from witnesses.<ref name="Jewish Encyclopedia 1901"/> Unlike the biblical law protecting fugitive slaves, Maimonides argued that such slaves should be compelled to buy their freedom.<ref name="Jewish Encyclopedia 1901"/><ref name="Maimonides, Mishneh Torah"/>
At the same time, Maimonides and other [[Halacha|halachic]] authorities forbade or strongly discouraged any unethical treatment of slaves. According to the traditional Jewish law, a slave is more like an indentured servant, who has rights and should be treated almost like a member of the owner's family. Maimonides wrote that, regardless whether a slave is Jewish or not, "The way of the pious and the wise is to be compassionate and to pursue justice, not to overburden or oppress a slave, and to provide them from every dish and every drink. The early sages would give their slaves from every dish on their table. They would feed their servants before sitting to their own meals... Slaves may not be maltreated of offended - the law destined them for service, not for humiliation. Do not shout at them or be angry with them, but hear them out." In another context, Maimonides wrote that all the laws of slavery are "mercy, compassion and forbearance".<ref>Encyclopedia Judaica, 2007, vol. 18, p. 670</ref><ref>http://www.chabad.org/library/article_cdo/aid/305549/jewish/Torah-Slavery-and-the-Jews.htm</ref>
==Christianity==
{{main|Christianity and slavery}}
Slavery in different forms existed within [[Christianity]] for over 18 centuries. Although in the [[Early Christianity|early years of Christianity]], freeing slaves was regarded as an act of charity,<ref name="Slavery in the Middle Ages">{{cite web|url=http://historymedren.about.com/library/weekly/aa012698.htm|title=Slavery in the Middle Ages|author=Melissa Snell|work=About|accessdate=23 October 2014}}</ref> and the Christian view of equality of all people including slaves was a novelty in the Roman Empire,<ref name=Catholic>{{cite encyclopedia |last=Allard |first=Paul |title=Slavery and Christianity |encyclopedia=Catholic Encyclopedia |volume=XIV |publisher=Robert Appleton Company |location=New York |year=1912 |url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/14036a.htm |accessdate=15 October 2009}}</ref> the institution of slavery was rarely criticised. Indeed, in 340, the [[Synod of Gangra]] condemned the [[Manicheanism|Manicheans]] for their urging that slaves should liberate themselves; the canons of the Synod instead declared that anyone preaching abolitionism should be anathematised, and that slaves had a "Christian obligation" to submit to their masters. [[Augustine of Hippo]], who renounced his former Manicheanism, argued that slavery was part of the mechanism to preserve the natural order of things;<ref>Augustine of Hippo, ''[[City of God (book)|City of God]]''</ref><ref>[[Elaine Pagels]], ''Adam, Eve, and the Serpent'' (1988), page 114</ref> [[John Chrysostom]], regarded as a saint by [[Eastern Orthodoxy]] and [[Roman Catholicism]], argued that slaves should be resigned to their fate, as by "obeying his master he is obeying God".<ref>[[Henri Daniel-Rops]], ''Cathedral and Crusade'' (1957), page 263</ref> but also stated that "Slavery is the fruit of covetousness, of extravagance, of insatiable greediness" in his Epist. ad Ephes.<ref>http://medicolegal.tripod.com/catholicsvslavery.htm Leroy J. Pletten, Roman Catholic Church Opposition to Slavery (2005)</ref> As the Apostle Paul admonished the early Christians; "There is neither Jew nor Greek: there is neither bond nor free: there is neither male nor female. For you are all one in Christ Jesus". And in fact, even some of the first popes were once slaves themselves.<ref name=Catholic />
In 1452 [[Pope Nicholas V]] issued the papal bull [[Dum Diversas]], which granted Afonso V of Portugal the right to reduce any "Saracens, pagans and any other unbelievers" to hereditary slavery. The approval of slavery under these conditions was reaffirmed and extended in his Romanus Pontifex bull of 1455. (This was regarding wars caused by the fall on constantinople) In 1488 [[Pope Innocent VIII]] accepted the gift of 100 slaves from [[Ferdinand II of Aragon]] and distributed those slaves to his cardinals and the Roman nobility. Also, in 1639 [[Pope Urban VIII]] purchased slaves for himself from the [[Knights Hospitaller|Knights of Malta]].<ref>{{cite book | last = Bermejo, S.J. | first = Luis M. | title = Infallibity on Trial | publisher = Christian Classics, Inc. | location = London | year = 1992 | pages = 315–316 | isbn = 0-87061-190-9}}</ref>
Other Popes in the 15th and 16th century denounced slavery as a ''great crime'', including [[Pope Pius II|Pius II]],<ref name=Catholic /> [[Pope Paul III|Paul III]],<ref>Alessandro Farnese, ''[[Sublimus Dei]]'' (1537) - [http://www.papalencyclicals.net/Paul03/p3subli.htm online copy]</ref> and [[Pope Eugene IV|Eugene IV]].<ref>Gabriele Condulmer, ''[[Sicut Dudum]]'' (1435) - [http://www.papalencyclicals.net/Eugene04/eugene04sicut.htm online copy]</ref> In 1639, pope Urban VIII forbade slavery, as did Benedict XIV in 1741. In 1815, pope Pius VII demanded of the Congress of Vienna the suppression of the slave trade, and Gregory XVI condemned it again in 1839.<ref name=Catholic />
In addition, the Dominican friars who arrived at the Spanish settlement at Santo Domingo in 1510 strongly denounced the enslavement of the local Indians. Along with other priests, they opposed their treatment as unjust and illegal in an audience with the Spanish king and in the subsequent royal commission.<ref>{{cite book | last = Thomas | first = Hugh | title = Rivers of Gold: The Rise of the Spanish Empire | publisher = Weidenfeld & Nicolson | location = London | year = 2003| pages = 258–262 | isbn = 0-297-64563-3}}</ref> As a response to this position, the Spanish monarchy's subsequent ''[[Requerimiento]]'' provided a religious justification for the enslavement of the local populations, on the pretext of refusing conversion to Roman Catholicism and therefore denying the authority of the Pope.<ref>{{cite book | last = Thomas | first = Hugh | title = Rivers of Gold: The Rise of the Spanish Empire | publisher = Weidenfeld & Nicolson | location = London | year = 2003| pages = 266 | isbn = 0-297-64563-3}}</ref>
Some other Christian organizations were slaveholders. The 18th century high-church Anglican [[Society for the Propagation of the Gospel in Foreign Parts]] owned the Codrington Plantation, in [[Barbados]], containing several hundred slaves, branded on their chests with the word ''Society''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/4694896.stm|title=BBC News story about a belated official apology for the Society's crimes|publisher=|accessdate=23 October 2014}}</ref><ref>Adam Hochschild, ''Bury the Chains, The British Struggle to Abolish Slavery'' (2005), page 61</ref> [[George Whitefield]], famed for his sparking of the so-called ''[[Great Awakening]]'' of American evangelicalism, overturned a province-wide ban against slavery,<ref>Arnold Dallimore, ''George Whitefield: The Life and Times of the Great Evangelist of the Eighteenth Century'' (1980), Volume 2</ref> and went on to own several hundred slaves himself.<ref>Edward J. Cashin, ''Beloved Bethesda : A History of George Whitefield's Home for Boys'' (2001)</ref> Yet Whitefield is remembered as one of the first to preach [[History of slavery in Georgia (U.S. state)|to the enslaved]].<ref>[http://www.christiancentury.org/blogs/archive/2015-01/george-whitefield-s-troubled-relationship-race-and-slavery Thomas S. Kidd, “George Whitefield’s Troubled Relationship to Race and Slavery” (''Christian Century'', Jan 07, 2015)]</ref>
At other times, Christian groups worked against slavery. The seventh century [[Saint Eligius|Saint Eloi]] used his vast wealth to purchase British and Saxon slaves in groups of 50 and 100 in order to set them free.<ref>Life in Medieval Times by Marjorie Rowling</ref> The [[Religious Society of Friends|Quakers]] in particular were early leaders in [[abolitionism]], attacking slavery since at least 1688. In 1787 the [[Society for Effecting the Abolition of the Slave Trade]] was formed, with 9 of the 12 founder members being Quakers; [[William Wilberforce]], an early supporter of the society, went on to push through the [[Slave Trade Act 1807|1807 Slave Trade Act]], striking a major blow against the transatlantic slave trade. Leaders of [[Methodism]] and [[Presbyterianism]] also vehemently denounced human bondage,<ref>Thoughts Upon Slavery, John Wesley, Published in the year 1774, John Wesley: Holiness of Heart and Life, 1996 Ruth A. Daugherty</ref><ref>Charles G. Finney, Memoirs (New York: A.S. Barnes, 1876), 324</ref><ref>Wylie, Samuel Brown, D.D., Memoir of Alexander McLeod, D.D., New York (New York: Charles Scribner, 145 Nassau Street, 1855), 51</ref> convincing their congregations to do likewise; Methodists<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ket.org/underground/history/westexpansion.htm|title=KET's Underground Railroad - Westward Expansion and the Development of Abolitionist Thought|author=M Ginter|work=ket.org|accessdate=8 November 2015}}</ref> and Presbyterians<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pcahistory.org/findingaids/rpcgs/mcleod.html|title=Alexander McLeod's stand against slavery|author=PCA Historical Center Archivist|work=pcahistory.org|accessdate=1 July 2018}}</ref> subsequently made the repudiation of slavery a condition of membership.
In the [[Southern United States]], however, support for slavery was strong; [[Abolitionism in the United States|anti-slavery]] literature was prevented from passing through the postal system, and even sermons, from the famed English preacher [[Charles Spurgeon]], were burned due to their censure of slavery.<ref>The Christian Cabinet, Dec. 14 1859</ref> When the [[American Civil War]] broke out, slavery became one of the issues which would be decided by its outcome; the southern defeat led to a [[Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|constitutional ban on slavery]]. Despite the general emancipation of slaves, members of fringe Christian groups like the [[Christian Identity]] movement, and the [[Ku Klux Klan]] (a [[White supremacy|white supremacist]] group) see the enslavement of Africans as a positive aspect of American history.
===Slave Christianity===
In the [[United States]], Christianity not only held views about slavery but also on how slaves practiced their own form of Christianity. Prior to the work of [[Melville Herskovits]] in 1941, it was widely believed that all elements of African culture were destroyed by the horrific experiences of Africans forced to come to the United States of America. Since his groundbreaking work, scholarship has found that Slave Christianity existed as an extraordinarily creative patchwork of African and Christian religious tradition.<ref>Charles H. Lippy, "Slave Christianity" in ''Modern Christianity to 1900: A People's History of Christianity'', ed. Amanda Porterfield (Minneapolis: Fortress Press, 2007), 291-292.</ref> The slaves brought with them a wide variety of religious traditions including both tribal shamanism and [[Islam]]. Beyond that, tribal traditions could vary to a high degree across the African continent.
During the early eighteenth century, Anglican missionaries attempting to bring Christianity to slaves in the Southern colonies often found themselves butting up against not only uncooperative masters, but also resistant slaves. An unquestionable obstacle to the acceptance of Christianity among slaves was their desire to continue to adhere as much as possible to the religious beliefs and rituals of their African ancestors. Missionaries working in the South were especially displeased with slave retention of African practices such as polygamy and what they called idolatrous dancing. In fact, even blacks who embraced Christianity in America did not completely abandon Old World religion. Instead, they engaged in syncretism, blending Christian influences with traditional African rites and beliefs. Symbols and objects, such as crosses, were conflated with charms carried by Africans to ward off evil spirits. Christ was interpreted as a healer similar to the priests of Africa. In the New World, fusions of African spirituality and Christianity led to distinct new practices among slave populations, including voodoo or vodun in Haiti and Spanish Louisiana. Although African religious influences were also important among Northern blacks, exposure to Old World religions was more intense in the South, where the density of the black population was greater.
There were, however, some commonalities across the majority of tribal traditions. Perhaps the primary understanding of tribal traditions was that there was not a separation of the sacred and the secular.<ref name="Charles H. Lippy 2007">Charles H. Lippy, "Slave Christianity" in ''Modern Christianity to 1900: A People's History of Christianity'', ed. Amanda Porterfield (Minneapolis: Fortress Press, 2007), 295.</ref> All life was sacred and the supernatural was present in every facet and focus of life. Most tribal traditions highlighted this experience of the supernatural in ecstatic experiences of the supernatural brought on by ritual song and dance. Repetitious music and dancing were often used to bring on these experiences through the use of drums and chanting. The realization of these experiences was in the "possession" of a worshipper in which one not only is taken over by the divine but actually becomes one with the divine.<ref name="Charles H. Lippy 2007"/>
Echoes of African tribal traditions can be seen in the Christianity practiced by slaves in the Americas. The song, dance, and ecstatic experiences of traditional tribal religion were Christianized and practiced by slaves in what is called the "Ring Shout." <ref>Charles H. Lippy, "Slave Christianity" in ''Modern Christianity to 1900: A People's History of Christianity'', ed. Amanda Porterfield (Minneapolis: Fortress Press, 2007), 299-300.</ref> This practice was a major mark of African American Christianity during the slavery period.
Christianity came more slowly to the slaves of North America. Many colonial slaveholders feared that baptizing slaves would lead to emancipation because of vague laws concerning the slave status of Christians under British colonial rule. Even after 1706, by which time many states had passed laws stating that baptism would not alter slave status, slaveholders were worried that the catechization of slaves wouldn't be a wise economic choice. Slaves usually had one day off each week, usually Sunday. That time was used to grow their own crops, as well as dancing and singing (doing such things on the Sabbath was frowned on by most preachers), so there was little time for slaves to receive religious instruction.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Slave Religion : The Invisible Institution in the Antebellum South.|last=Raboteau|first=Albert J.|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2004|isbn=0-19-517412-7|location=USA|pages=39-75}}</ref>
During the antebellum period, slave preachers - enslaved or formally enslaved evangelists - became instrumental in shaping slave Christianity. They preached a gospel radically different from that of white preachers, who often used Christianity in an attempt to make slaves more complacent to their enslaved status. Rather than focusing on obedience, slave preachers placed a greater emphasis on the Old Testament, especially the book of Exodus. They likened the plight of the American slaves to the enslaved Hebrews of the Bible, instilling hope into the hearts of those enslaved. Slave preachers were instrumental in shaping the religious landscape of African Americans for decades to come.<ref>Dennard, David C. "Religion in the quarters: a study of slave preachers in the antebellum South, 1800-1860." (1984): 3465-3465.</ref>
==Islam== {{main|Islamic views on slavery|Arab slave trade|Slavery in the Ottoman Empire|Ma malakat aymanukum|Muhammad's slaves|Slavery in 21st century Islamism}} According to [[Bernard Lewis]], slavery has been a part of Islam's history from its beginning. The Quran like the Old and the New Testaments, states Lewis, "assumes the existence of slavery".<ref name="Lewis1992p5"/> It attempts to regulate slavery and thereby implicitly accepts it.<ref>{{cite book|author=Bernard Lewis|title=Race and Slavery in the Middle East: An Historical Enquiry|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WdjvedBeMHYC|year= 1992|publisher= Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-505326-5|page=5|quote= The Qur'an, like the Old and the New Testaments, assumes the existence of slavery. It regulates the practice of the institution and thus implicitly accepts it. The Prophet Muhammad and those of his Companions who could afford it themselves owned slaves; some of them acquired more by conquest.}}</ref> [[Muhammad]] and his Companions owned slaves, and some of them acquired slaves through conquests.<ref name="Lewis1992p5">{{cite book|author=Bernard Lewis|title=Race and Slavery in the Middle East: An Historical Enquiry|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WdjvedBeMHYC|year= 1992|publisher= Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-505326-5|pages=5–6}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=John Ralph Willis|title= Slaves and Slavery in Muslim Africa: The servile estate|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=sasFc2yN7AcC |year= 1985|publisher= Routledge |isbn=978-0-7146-3201-8|pages=viii–ix}}</ref>
The [[Quran]] does forbid slavery, nor does it consider it as a permanent institution.<ref name="Smith2006p22"/> In various verses, it refers to slaves as "necks" (''raqabah'') or "those whom your right hand possesses" (''[[Ma malakat aymanukum]]'').<ref name="Smith2006p22">{{cite book|author=W. G. Clarence-Smith|title=Islam and the Abolition of Slavery|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nQbylEdqJKkC |year=2006|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-522151-0|pages=22–24}}</ref>{{refn|group=note|For example, Quran 4.3:{{cite quran|4|3}} "If ye fear that ye shall not be able to deal justly with the orphans, Marry women of your choice, Two or three or four; but if ye fear that ye shall not be able to deal justly (with them), then only one, or (a captive) that your right hands possess, that will be more suitable, to prevent you from doing injustice".<ref name=ali39>{{cite book | last=Ali | first=Kecia | title=Sexual ethics and Islam : feminist reflections on Qur'an, hadith, and jurisprudence | publisher=Oxford University Press | location=Oxford, England | year=2006 | isbn=978-1-85168-456-4 | page=39-41, 168 note 7, 170 note 44}}</ref><br>Quran 16.71:{{cite quran|16|71}} "Allah has bestowed His gifts of sustenance more freely on some of you than on others: those more favoured are not going to throw back their gifts to those whom their right hands possess, so as to be equal in that respect. Will they then deny the favours of Allah?"<ref name=ali39/><br>Quran 23:5:{{cite quran|23|5}} "And who guard their modesty, Quran 23:6: Save from their wives or the (slaves) that their right hands possess, for then they are not blameworthy."<ref name=ali39/><br>Other examples: Quran 4:25, 4:28, 24:33, 24:58, 33:50, etc<ref>{{cite book | last=Ali | first=Kecia | title=Sexual ethics and Islam : feminist reflections on Qur'an, hadith, and jurisprudence | publisher=Oxford University Press | location=Oxford, England | year=2006 | isbn=978-1-85168-456-4 | page=39-45}}</ref><ref name=allain49/>}} In addition to these terms for slaves, the Quran and early Islamic literature uses '''Abd'' (male) and ''Amah'' (female) term for an enslaved and servile possession, as well as other terms. According to Brockopp, seven separate terms for slaves appear in the Quran, in at least twenty nine Quranic verses.<ref name="Brockopp2000p128">{{cite book|author=Jonathan E. Brockopp|title=Early Mālikī Law: Ibn ʻAbd Al-Ḥakam and His Major Compendium of Jurisprudence |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ciSskcBCi3EC |year=2000|publisher=BRILL Academic|isbn=90-04-11628-1|pages=128–130, 162–163}}</ref><ref name=allain49>{{cite book|author=Jean Allain|title=The Legal Understanding of Slavery: From the Historical to the Contemporary|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=62t3a5iESy8C |year=2012|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-164535-8|pages=49–52 with footnotes}}</ref><ref>{{Cite encyclopedia|author=Brockopp, Jonathan E.| origyear=1986 | title=Slaves and Slavery |encyclopedia=Encyclopaedia of Quran | volume =5 |year= 2005|publisher=Brill |editor=Jane Dammen McAuliffe|doi=10.1163/1875-3922_q3_EQSIM_00393}}, Quote: "Slaves are mentioned in at least twenty-nine verses of the Qurʾān, most of these are Medinan and refer to the legal status of slaves. Seven separate terms refer to slaves, the most common of which is the phrase “that which your/their right hands own” (mā malakat aymānukum/aymānuhum/aymānuhunna/yamīnuka), found in fifteen places."</ref>
The Quran assigns the same spiritual value to a slave as to a free man,<ref name=EI2-quran>{{Cite encyclopedia|author=Brunschvig, R.| year=1986 | title=ʿAbd |encyclopedia=Encyclopaedia of Islam| edition=2nd|publisher=Brill |editors=P. Bearman, Th. Bianquis, C.E. Bosworth, E. van Donzel, W.P. Heinrichs|volume=1|pages=25|doi=10.1163/1573-3912_islam_COM_0003|quote=THE KOR'AN. [...] Spiritually, the slave has the same value as the free man [...] over and over again, from beginning to end of the Preaching, it makes the emancipation of slaves a meritorious act: a work of charity (ii, 177; xc,13), to which the legal alms may be devoted (ix,60), or a deed of expiation for certain felonies (unintentional homicide: iv, 92, where "a believing slave" is specified; perjury: v, 89; Iviii, 3);}}</ref><ref>Gordon, Murray. Slavery in the Arab World (p. 35). New Amsterdam Books. Kindle Edition. Quote: "At a spiritual level, the slave was possessed of the same value as a freeman."</ref> and a believing slave is regarded as superior to a free pagan or idolator.<ref>{{cite book|author=Bernard Lewis|title=Race and Slavery in the Middle East: An Historical Enquiry|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WdjvedBeMHYC|year= 1992|publisher= Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-505326-5|page=5|quote= the believing slave is now the brother of the freeman in Islam and before God, and the superior of the free pagan or idolator (11:221).}}</ref> The manumission of slaves is regarded as a meritorious act in the Quran, and is recommended either as an act of charity or as expiation for sins.<ref name=EI2-quran/><ref>{{cite book|author=Bernard Lewis|title=Race and Slavery in the Middle East: An Historical Enquiry|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WdjvedBeMHYC|year= 1992|publisher= Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-505326-5|page=5|quote=The freeing of slaves is recommended both for the expiation of sins (IV:92; V:92; LVIII:3) and as an act of simple benevolence (11:177; XXIV:33; XC:13).}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Bernard K. Freamon|chapter=Definitions and Conceptions of Slave Ownership in Islamic Law|editor=Jean Allain|title=The Legal Understanding of Slavery: From the Historical to the Contemporary|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=62t3a5iESy8C |year=2012|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-164535-8|page=52|quote=Several of these verses mandate the freeing of slaves as expiation for sin or crimes and they also establish the emancipation of a slave as a meritorious and pious act, entitling the emancipator to favorable treatment in the next life.}}</ref> While the spiritual value of a slave was same as the freeman, states Forough Jahanbakhsh, in regards to earthly matters, a slave was not an equal to the freeman and relegated to an inferior status.<ref>{{cite book|author=Forough Jahanbakhsh|title=Islam, Democracy and Religious Modernism in Iran, 1953-2000: From Bāzargān to Soroush|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=m6Q5NumP2ccC |year=2001|publisher=BRILL|isbn=90-04-11982-5|pages=36–37}}</ref> In Quran and for its many commentators, states Ennaji, there is a fundamental distinction between free Muslims and slaves, a basic constituent of its social organization, an irreparable dichotomy introduced by the existence of believers and infidels.<ref>{{cite book|author=Mohammed Ennaji|title=Slavery, the State, and Islam|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8zesirKffoEC&pg=PA54 |year=2013|publisher= Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-11962-7|page= 41}}, Quote: "The Koran addresses with this statement the community of free Muslims, according to many commentators, thereby establishing a distinction between statuses. In Muslim society, slavery was one of the manifestations and fundamental constituents of the social organization. The very existence of believers and infidels irreparably induces the dichotomy between free men and slaves, two contradictory and complementary statuses. There could be no infidels without believers, no paradise without hell, no free men without slaves".</ref>
The corpus of [[hadith]] attributed to Muhammad or his Companions contains a large store of reports enjoining kindness toward slaves.<ref>{{Cite encyclopedia|author=Brunschvig, R.| year=1986 | title=ʿAbd |encyclopedia=Encyclopaedia of Islam| edition=2nd|publisher=Brill |editors=P. Bearman, Th. Bianquis, C.E. Bosworth, E. van Donzel, W.P. Heinrichs|volume=1|pages=25|doi=10.1163/1573-3912_islam_COM_0003|quote=Tradition delights in asserting that the slave's lot was among the latest preoccupations of the Prophet. It has quite a large store of sayings and anecdotes, attributed to the Prophet or to his Companions, enjoining real kindness towards this inferior social class.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Bernard Lewis|title=Race and Slavery in the Middle East: An Historical Enquiry|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WdjvedBeMHYC|year= 1992|publisher= Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-505326-5|page=6|quote= This point is emphasized and elaborated in innumerable hadiths (traditions), in which the Prophet is quoted as urging considerate and sometimes even equal treatment for slaves, denouncing cruelty, harshness, or even discourtesy, recommending the liberation of slaves, and reminding the Muslims that his apostolate was to free and slave alike.}}</ref> Chouki El Hamel has argued that the Quran recommends gradual abolition of slavery,<ref>{{cite book|title=Black Morocco: A History of Slavery, Race, and Islam|author=Chouki El Hamel|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2014|page=36|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UwogAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA36|quote=These verses recommend gradual steps to end slavery. As Muhammad Asad points out, "the institution of slavery is envisaged in the Quran as a mere historic phenomenon that must in time be abolished." Indeed, the Qur'anic prescriptions of manumission are expressed in the Qur'an as pious deeds, clearly implying that ending slavery was a crucial goal in Islam at times when slavery formed a fundamental part of human culture.}}</ref> and that some hadith are consistent with that message while others contradict it.<ref>{{cite book|title=Black Morocco: A History of Slavery, Race, and Islam|author=Chouki El Hamel|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2014|page=39|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UwogAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA39|quote=Ironically the Hadith did not specifically advocate the abolition of slavery; instead the Hadith was used to create practical advancement in the history of slavery. I want to illustrate this by citing examples from ''as-Sahih'' of al-Bukhari that are consistent or contradictory with the message of the Qur'an.}}</ref>
According to Dror Ze'evi, early Islamic dogma set out to improve conditions of human bondage. It forbade enslavement of free members of Islamic society, including non-Muslims (''[[dhimmis]]'') residing under Islamic rule. Islam also allowed the acquisition of lawful non-Muslim slaves who were imprisoned, slaves purchased from lands outside the Islamic state, as well as considered the boys or girls born to slaves as slaves.<ref name=OEIW>{{cite encyclopedia|author=Dror Ze’evi|title=Slavery|encyclopedia=The Oxford Encyclopedia of the Islamic World|editor=John L. Esposito|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford|year=2009| page=79| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LeYpAQAAMAAJ}}</ref> Islamic law treats a free man and a slave unequally in sentencing for an equivalent crime.<ref>{{cite book|author=Humphrey J. Fisher|title=Slavery in the History of Muslim Black Africa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wyDYZsacNioC |year=2001|publisher=New York University Press|isbn=978-0-8147-2716-4|pages=14–16}}</ref> For example, traditional Sunni jurisprudence, with the exception of Hanafi law, objects to putting a free man to death for killing a slave.<ref>{{Cite encyclopedia|author=Brunschvig, R.| year=1986 | title=ʿAbd |encyclopedia=Encyclopaedia of Islam| edition=2nd|publisher=Brill |editors=P. Bearman, Th. Bianquis, C.E. Bosworth, E. van Donzel, W.P. Heinrichs|volume=1|pages=29|doi=10.1163/1573-3912_islam_COM_0003|quote=the schools object to putting a free man to death for killing a slave, with the noteworthy exception of the Hanafis (and also of that illustrious, albeit somewhat dissident, Hanbali, Ibn Taymiyya [...]), and even they exempt the man who kills his own slave or one belonging to his son}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |first=Rudolph|last=Peters| year=2006 | title=Crime and Punishment in Islamic Law: Theory and Practice from the Sixteenth to the Twenty-First Century|publisher=Cambridge University Press|page=47|quote=The Hanafites, however, follow a different criterion with regard to retaliation for homicide. For them the permanent protection of life ('isma) is the basis of the required equivalence and not the value of the bloodprice. Thus in Hanafite law a Muslim may be executed for killing a dhimmı (but not for killing a musta'min because his protection is only temporary), and a free man for killing a slave.}}</ref> A slave who commits a crime may receive the same punishment as a free man, a punishment half as severe, or the master may be responsible for paying the damages, depending on the crime.<ref>{{Cite encyclopedia|author=Brunschvig, R.| year=1986 | title=ʿAbd |encyclopedia=Encyclopaedia of Islam| edition=2nd|publisher=Brill |editors=P. Bearman, Th. Bianquis, C.E. Bosworth, E. van Donzel, W.P. Heinrichs|volume=1|pages=29|doi=10.1163/1573-3912_islam_COM_0003}}</ref> According to Ze'evi, Islam considered the master to own the slave's labor, a slave to be his master's property to be sold or bought at will, and that the master was entitled to slave's sexual submission.<ref name=OEIW/>
The Islamic law ([[sharia]]) allows the taking of [[infidel]]s (non-Muslims) as slaves, during religious wars also called holy wars or ''jihad''.<ref>{{cite book|author=W. G. Clarence-Smith|title=Islam and the Abolition of Slavery|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nQbylEdqJKkC |year= 2006|publisher= Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-522151-0|pages=25–26}}</ref> In the early Islamic communities, according to [[Kecia Ali]], "both life and law were saturated with slaves and slavery".<ref>{{cite book|author=Kecia Ali|title=Marriage and Slavery in Early Islam|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=C229nbjq8TMC |year=2010|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=978-0-674-05917-7|pages=6–7}}</ref> War, tribute from vassal states, purchase and children who inherited their parent's slavery were the sources of slaves in Islam.<ref name=carl1114>{{cite book|author=Carl Skutsch|title=Encyclopedia of the World's Minorities |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=yXYKAgAAQBAJ |year=2013| publisher= Routledge| isbn=978-1-135-19388-1|pages=1114-1115}}, Quote: "Islam and Slavery. (...) Slaves were obtained through purchase, conquest, and as tribute from vassal states. Children of slaves were also slaves."</ref> In Islam, according to [[Paul Lovejoy]], "the religious requirement that new slaves be pagans and need for continued imports to maintain slave population made Africa an important source of slaves for the Islamic world."<ref>{{cite book|author=Paul E. Lovejoy|title=Transformations in Slavery: A History of Slavery in Africa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dXVFnHqhLvcC|year=2011 |publisher=Cambridge University Press| isbn=978-1-139-50277-1|pages=16–17}}</ref> Slavery of non-Muslims, followed by the structured process of converting them to Islam then encouraging the freeing of the converted slave, states Lovejoy helped the growth of Islam after its conquests.<ref>{{cite book|author=Paul E. Lovejoy|title=Transformations in Slavery: A History of Slavery in Africa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dXVFnHqhLvcC|year=2011|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-139-50277-1|pages=16–18}}; Quote: "In Islamic tradition, slavery was perceived as a means of converting non-Muslims. One task of the master was religious instruction and theoretically Muslims could not be enslaved. Conversion (of a non-Muslim to Islam) did not automatically lead to emancipation, but assimilation into Muslim society was deemed a prerequisite for emancipation (...)"</ref>
According to Mohammed Ennaji, the ownership gave the master a right "to punish one's slave".<ref>{{cite book|author=Mohammed Ennaji|title=Slavery, the State, and Islam|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8zesirKffoEC&pg=PA54 |year=2013|publisher= Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-11962-7|page= 54}}</ref> In Islam, a child inherited slavery if he or she was born to a slave mother and slave father.<ref>{{cite book|author=Bernard Lewis|title=Islam in History: Ideas, People, and Events in the Middle East|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h5tjQSU4Ex0C |year=2011|publisher=Open Court|isbn=978-0-8126-9757-5|page=252}}</ref> However, if the child was born to a slave mother and her owner master, then the child was free. Slaves could be given as property (dower) during marriage.<ref>{{cite book|author=Jean Allain|title=The Legal Understanding of Slavery: From the Historical to the Contemporary|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=62t3a5iESy8C |year=2012|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-164535-8|pages=52–55 with footnotes}}</ref> The text encourages Muslim men to take slave women as sexual partners (concubines), or marry them.<ref name=ali39/> Islam, states Lewis, did not permit ''Dhimmis'' (non-Muslims) "to own Muslim slaves; and if a slave owned by a dhimmi embraced Islam, his owner was legally obliged to free or sell him". There was also a gradation in the status on the slave, and his descendants, after the slave converted to Islam.<ref>{{cite book|author=Bernard Lewis|title=Race and Slavery in the Middle East: An Historical Enquiry|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WdjvedBeMHYC|year= 1992|publisher= Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-505326-5|pages=5–8, 85-86}}; Quote: "They [Dhimmis] were not permitted to own Muslim slaves; and if a slave owned by a dhimmi embraced Islam, his owner was legally obliged to free or sell him." (...) "Non-Muslims are of course excluded. But that is not all. A convert is not as good as the son of a convert; the son of a convert is not as good as the grandson of a convert. Here too the rule is limited to three generations, after which all are equal in their Islam".</ref>
Under Islamic law, in "what might be called civil matters", a slave was "a chattel with no legal powers or rights whatsoever", states Lewis. A slave could not own or inherit property or enter into a contract. However, he was better off in terms of rights than Greek or Roman slaves.<ref>{{cite book|author=Bernard Lewis|title=Race and Slavery in the Middle East: An Historical Enquiry|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=WdjvedBeMHYC |year= 1992|publisher= Oxford University Press|isbn= 978-0-19-505326-5|page= 7}}; Quote: "In what might be called civil matters, the slave was a chattel with no legal powers or rights whatsoever. He could not enter into a contract, hold property or inherit. If he incurred a fine, his owner was responsible. He was, however, distinctly better off, in the matter of rights, than a Greek or Roman slave"</ref> According to Chirag Ali, the early Muhammadans misinterpreted the Quran as sanctioning "polygamy, arbitrary divorce, slavery, concubinage and religious wars", and he states that the Quranic injunctions are against all this.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=W4OKaz5dzdYC |title=Modernist Islam, 1840-1940: A Sourcebook|editor= Charles Kurzman| author= Chirag Ali| publisher= Oxford University Press|page= 288}}</ref> According to Ron Shaham and other scholars, the various jurisprudence systems on Sharia such as [[Maliki]], [[Hanafi]], [[Shafi'i]], [[Hanbali]] and others differ in their interpretation of the Islamic law on slaves.<ref>{{cite book|author=Ron Shaham|title=The Expert Witness in Islamic Courts |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MCCIsWZlabQC |year=2010|publisher=University of Chicago Press|isbn=978-0-226-74935-8|pages=68–71}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=W. G. Clarence-Smith|title=Islam and the Abolition of Slavery|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nQbylEdqJKkC |year= 2006|publisher= Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-522151-0|pages=20–21, 73–74}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Jean Allain|title=The Legal Understanding of Slavery: From the Historical to the Contemporary|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=n_KAvAjkEbsC |year=2012|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-966046-9|pages=43–45, 52–53}}</ref>
Slaves were particularly numerous in Muslim armies. Slave armies were deployed by Sultans and Caliphs at various medieval era war fronts across the Islamic Empires,<ref name=carl1114/><ref>{{cite book|author=André Wink|title=Al-Hind the Making of the Indo-Islamic World |year=1997|publisher=BRILL Academic|isbn=90-04-10236-1|pages=3, 90–92}}</ref> playing an important role in the expansion of Islam in [[Africa]] and elsewhere.<ref>{{cite book|author=Ira M. Lapidus|title=A History of Islamic Societies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZkJpBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA86|year=2014|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-139-99150-6|pages=86, 177–184, 323-325}}</ref> Slavery of men and women in Islamic states such as the [[Ottoman Empire]], states Ze'evi, continued through the early 20th-century.<ref name=OEIW/>
==Bahá'í Faith== {{main|Bahá'í Faith and slavery}}
[[Bahá'u'lláh]], founder of the [[Bahá'í Faith]], commended [[Queen Victoria]] for abolishing the slave trade in a letter written to Her Majesty between 1868-1872.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www-personal.umich.edu/~jrcole/bhkings.htm|title="Bahá'u'lláh's Tablets to the Rulers" by Juan R.I. Cole, Department of History, University of Michigan|publisher=|accessdate=23 October 2014}}</ref> Bahá'u'lláh also forbids slavery in the [[Kitáb-i-Aqdas]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/b/KA/ka-3.html|title="A Description of the Kitáb-i-Aqdas" page 14 by Shoghí Effendí Rabbání|publisher=|accessdate=23 October 2014}}</ref> written around 1873 considered by Bahá'ís to be the holiest book revealed by Bahá'u'lláh in which he states, "It is forbidden you to trade in slaves, be they men or women."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/b/KA/ka-5.html|title="The Kitáb-i-Aqdas" Paragraph 72 by Bahá'u'lláh|publisher=|accessdate=23 October 2014}}</ref>
Both the Báb and Bahá'u'lláh [[Slavery in Iran|owned slaves of African descent]] before the writing of the Kitab-i-Aqdas. While the Báb purchased several slaves, Bahá'u'lláh acquired his through inheritance and freed them. Bahá'u'lláh officially condemned slavery in 1874. 21st century scholarship has found that the Báb credited one of the slaves of his elders as having raised him and compares him favorably with his own father.<ref>{{cite journal | author1=Nader Saiedi |author2=Translated by Omid Ghaemmaghami | title =The Ethiopian King | journal =Baha’i Studies Review | volume =17 | issue = | pages =181–186 | date =2011 | language =English | url =http://bahaiteachings.org/a-slave-educates-a-prophet | doi =10.1386/bsr.17.181/7 | access-date = Sep 7, 2016}}</ref> Work has continued on other recent finds in archives such as a very early document of Bahá'u'lláh's explaining his emancipating his slave because as all humans are symbolically slaves of God none can be owned by another<ref>{{cite web | url =http://bahaiteachings.org/bahaullah-frees-the-slaves | title =Baha’u’llah Frees the Slaves | author=Christopher Buck | date =January 13, 2014 | website =Bahaiteachings.org | access-date =Sep 7, 2016 }}</ref> saying "How, then, can this thrall claim for himself ownership of any other human being? Nay,…."<ref>{{cite web | url =http://bahaiteachings.org/liberating-every-slave | title =Liberating Every Slave |author=Christopher Buck | date =September 24, 2014 | website =Bahaiteachings.org | access-date =Sep 7, 2016 }}</ref>
==Hinduism== Hindu [[Vedas]] regard liberation to be the ultimate goal which is contrary to slavery.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=KvL3CQAAQBAJ&pg=PA53&dq=hinduism Religions and Nonviolence: The Rise of Effective Advocacy for Peace: The Rise of Effective Advocacy for Peace], p. 53, ABC-CLIO, Rachel M. MacNair</ref> Hindu [[Smriti]]s condemn slavery.<ref>{{cite book|title=Handbook of International Humanitarian Law in South Asia|page=36|publisher=Oxford University Press|first=Venkateshwara|last=Subramaniam Mani}}</ref>
The term "dasa" (dāsa) in ancient Hindu text is loosely translated as "slave."{{sfn|Kumar|1993|p=114}} However, the meaning of the term varied over time. R. S. Sharma, in his 1958 book, for example, states that the only word which could possibly mean slave in Rigveda is dāsa, and this sense of use is traceable to four later verses in Rigveda.{{sfn|R. S. Sharma|1958|pp=(1990:24-26)}} The term dāsa in the Rigveda, has been also been translated as a servant or enemy, and the identity of this term remains unclear and disputed among scholars.{{Sfn|West|2008|p=182}}{{refn|group=note|[a] HH Wilson translates dāsa in Rigvedic instances identified by R.S. Sharma, such as in verse 10.62.10, as servant rather than slave.<ref>[https://archive.org/stream/rigvedasanhitc06wils#page/166/mode/2up Rigveda 10.62.10] HH Wilson (Translator), Trubner & Co, page 167</ref><ref name="Wash Edward Hale 1999 page 162">Wash Edward Hale (1999), Ásura- in Early Vedic Religion, Motilal Barnarsidass, {{ISBN|978-8120800618}}, page 162</ref><br>[b] Michael Witzel suggests that the term ''dāsa'' in Sanskrit corresponds to North [[Iran]]ian tribe; Iranian (Latin) Dahae, (Greek) Daai; and that ''dāsa'' word may be memory of Indo-Aryan migration;<ref>{{cite journal |last=Witzel |first=Michael |authorlink=Michael Witzel |title=Autochthonous Aryans? |journal=Electronic Journal of Vedic Studies |volume=7 |number=3 |year=2001 |p=16 |url=http://archiv.ub.uni-heidelberg.de/savifadok/volltexte/2008/118}}</ref> with George Samuel stating that ''dāsa'' may be equivalent for "aborigines, servant or slave".<ref>{{Citation |last=Samuel |first=Geoffrey |title=The Origins of Yoga and Tantra |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=2008 |isbn=978-0-521-69534-3 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=JAvrTGrbpf4C |page=52}}</ref>}}
The word ''dāsi'' is found in Rigveda and Atharvaveda, states R.S. Sharma, which he states represented "a small servile class of women slaves".{{sfn|R. S. Sharma|1958|loc=pp. 22-24 (1990:24-26)}} Slavery in Vedic period, according to him, was mostly confined to women employed as domestic workers.{{sfn|R. S. Sharma|1958|p=(1990:103)}} He translates ''dasi'' in a Vedic era Upanishad as "maid-servant".{{sfn|R. S. Sharma|1958|p=45 (1990:50-51)}} Male slaves are rarely mentioned in the Vedic texts.{{sfn|R. S. Sharma|1958|p=45 (1990:50-51)}} The word dāsa occurs in the Hindu Sruti texts Aitareya and Gopatha Brahmanas, but not in the sense of a slave.{{sfn|R. S. Sharma|1958|p=45 (1990:50-51)}}
Towards the end of the Vedic period (600 BCE), a new system of ''varnas'' had appeared, with people called [[shudra]]s replacing the erstwhile ''dasas''. Some of the ''shudras'' were employed as labouring masses on farm land, much like "[[helots]] of [[Sparta]]", even though they were not treated with the same degree of coercion and contempt.{{sfn|R. S. Sharma|1958|p=48 (1990:53)}} They could be given away as gifts along with the land, which came in for criticism from the religious texts ''Āśvalāyana'' and ''Kātyāyana'' ''[[Srautasutra|Śrautasūtra]]s''.{{sfn|R. S. Sharma|1958|p=46 (1990:51-52)}} The term ''dasa'' was now employed to designate such enslaved people.{{sfn|R. S. Sharma|1958|p=91 (1990:103)}} Slavery arose out of debt, sale by parents or oneself (due to famines), judicial decree or fear. The slaves were differentiated by origin and different disabilities and rules for manumission applied. While this could happen to a person of any ''varna'', ''shudras'' were much more likely to be reduced to slavery.{{sfn|R. S. Sharma|1958|p=92 (1990:104)}}{{sfn|Kumar|1993|p=114}}
The [[Arthashastra]] laid down norms for the State to resettle ''shudra'' cultivators into new villages and providing them with land, grain, cattle and money.{{sfn|R. S. Sharma|1958|p=147 (1990:161-163)}} It also stated that ''aryas'' could not be subject to slavery and that the selling or mortgaging of a ''shudra'' was punishable unless he was a born slave.{{sfn|R. S. Sharma|1958|p=163 (1990:177)}}
==Buddhism== In Pali language Buddhist texts, ''Amaya-dasa'' has been translated by Davids and Stede in 1925, as a "slave by birth",<ref>Thomas William Rhys Davids, William Stede (2015 Reprint, Original: 1925), Pali-English Dictionary, 2nd Edition, Motilal Banarsidass, {{ISBN|978-8120811447}}, page 104</ref> ''Kila-dasa'' translated as a "bought slave",<ref>Thomas William Rhys Davids, William Stede (2015 Reprint, Original: 1925), Pali-English Dictionary, 2nd Edition, Motilal Banarsidass, {{ISBN|978-8120811447}}, page 217</ref> and ''Amata-dasa'' as "one who sees Amata (Sanskrit: ''Amrita'', nectar of immortality) or [[Nibbana]]".<ref>Thomas William Rhys Davids, William Stede (2015 Reprint, Original: 1925), Pali-English Dictionary, 2nd Edition, Motilal Banarsidass, {{ISBN|978-8120811447}}, page 73</ref> However, ''dasa'' in ancient texts can also mean "servant".<ref name=schopen>Gregory Schopen (2004), Buddhist Monks and Business Matters, University of Hawaii Press, {{ISBN|978-0824827748}}, page 201</ref>
Words related to ''dasa'' are found in early Buddhist texts, such as ''dāso na pabbājetabbo'', which Davids and Stede translate as "the slave cannot become a Bhikkhu".<ref name=davidsstedeped320>Thomas William Rhys Davids and William Stede (2015 Reprint, Original: 1925), Pali-English Dictionary, 2nd Edition, Motilal Banarsidass, {{ISBN|978-8120811447}}, page 320</ref> This restriction on who could become a Buddhist monk is found in Vinaya Pitakam i.93, [[Digha Nikaya]], [[Majjhima Nikāya]], Tibetan ''Bhiksukarmavakya'' and ''Upasampadajnapti''.<ref name=davidsstedeped320/><ref>Gregory Schopen (2010), On Some Who Are Not Allowed to Become Buddhist Monks or Nuns: An Old List of Types of Slaves or Unfree Laborers, Journal of the American Oriental Society, Vol. 130, No. 2, pages 225-234</ref> Schopen states that this translation of ''dasa'' as slave is disputed by scholars.<ref>Gregory Schopen (2010), On Some Who Are Not Allowed to Become Buddhist Monks or Nuns: An Old List of Types of Slaves or Unfree Laborers, Journal of the American Oriental Society, Vol. 130, No. 2, page 226</ref>
Early Buddhist texts in Pali, according to [[Ram Sharan Sharma|R. S. Sharma]], mention ''dāsa'' and ''kammakaras'', and they show that those who failed to pay their debts were enslaved, and Buddhism did not allow debtors and slaves to join their monasteries.{{sfn|R. S. Sharma|1958|p=(1990:103)}}
The Buddhist Emperor [[Ashoka]] banned slavery and renounced war.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=_BTKCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT130&dq=Ashoka The Multimedia Encyclopedia of Women in Today's World], p.130, SAGE publication, Mary Zeiss Stange, Carol K. Oyster, Jane E. Sloan</ref>

{{about|the traditional form of Buddhist chant in Cambodia|other uses|Smot (disambiguation)}}
'''Smot chanting''', or '''smot''' is a traditional form of [[Buddhist chant|Buddhist chanting]] in [[Buddhism in Cambodia|Cambodia]].
Smot is chanted at funerals and other ceremonies, and includes songs about the Buddha's life.<ref>{{Cite web |title = Smot Poetry Chanting |work = Cambodian Living Arts |accessdate = 2014-07-04 |date = 2014-01-22 |url = http://www.cambodianlivingarts.org/news/smot-poetry-chanting/ |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140714185431/http://www.cambodianlivingarts.org/news/smot-poetry-chanting/ |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 2014-07-14 }}</ref>
The texts used in smot are in [[Pali]] and [[Khmer language|Khmer]].
One famous chanter of smot was the monk Hun Horm (1924-2007) (later known as Hun Kang).<ref>{{Cite web |title = Smot - Preah Trey Leak Sang Khep by Hun Horm - |work = khmer24h.net |accessdate = 2014-07-04 |date = 2013-01-04 |url = http://buddhism.khmer24h.net/play.aspx?MediaID=s9R01ZlH5sCunqI |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140714181535/http://buddhism.khmer24h.net/play.aspx?MediaID=s9R01ZlH5sCunqI |archivedate = 2014-07-14 |df = }}</ref> Young artists who carry on the tradition are Sinat Nhok, and Pheuan Srey Peu (or Phoeun Srey Pov).<ref>[http://www.cambodianrefugeepoetry.org/docs/Cambodian_Poetry&Smot_National_Tour_APRIL2010.pdf Cambodian Poetry and Smot National Tour, April 2010] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714190040/http://www.cambodianrefugeepoetry.org/docs/Cambodian_Poetry%26Smot_National_Tour_APRIL2010.pdf |date=2014-07-14 }}</ref> Pheuan Srey Peu has studied with Prom Uth and Professor Yan Borin.<ref>{{Cite web | title = KI Media: Pheuan Srey Peu: The master of "smot" | work = KI-Media | accessdate = 2014-07-04 | date = 2008-12-28 | url = http://ki-media.blogspot.com/2008/12/pheuan-srey-peu-master-of-smot.html }}</ref>
The Cambodia Living Arts group seeks young people to study with the few remaining older masters of the art form.<ref>{{Cite web | title = Keeping an endangered Buddhist art form alive | work = Deutsche Welle - The Storytellers | accessdate = 2014-07-04 | date = 2014-04-06 | url = http://www.dw.de/keeping-an-endangered-buddhist-art-form-alive/a-17644920 }}</ref>
Presentations of smot have been given at the Khmer Arts Academy in [[Long Beach, California]].<ref>{{Cite web | title = Smot Music in Long Beach | work = Webbed Feet, Web Log » Blog Archive » I’m with the band | accessdate = 2014-07-04 | date = 2009-04-18 | url = http://jinja.apsara.org/2009/04/im-with-the-band-smot-music-in-long-beach/ }}</ref>

{{for|the botanical structure|Spathe}} [[file:Mykenischer Kulturkreis.png|thumb|Mycenian cultural environment (ca. 1400 BC)]] Among the first archaeological sites discovered in [[Mount Olympus]] was the excavation site '''Spathes''' (Greek Σπάθες, swords). It is a [[necropolis]] from the Late [[Bronze Age]]. The oldest tombs are from the 14th century BC, the last traces of the use were found from the end of the 13th century, the beginning of the 12th century BC. The settlement, associated with the necropolis, has not been found. Many of the burial offerings were made in the Mycenaean style, so that the Mycenaean cultural circle probably also (see also [[History of Pieria (regional unit)|History and archaeology Pierias]]) extended over the border of [[Thessaly]] to [[Pieria (regional unit)|Pieria]].<ref>Poulaki-Pandermali, Efi. ''Makedonikos Olympos''. Greek Ministry of Culture and Sport, 2013, pages 56 and 59</ref>
== Location == Near the village of Agios Dimitrios, on the border with Thessaly, in 1000 to 1100 meters altitude, on a hillside. The burial site runs from northeast to southwest direction.
== Excavation history == [[File:Spathes.jpg|thumb|Necropolis Spathes]] In 1975, the relevant archaeological authority was informed that several tombs (at least 12 to 13) were destroyed when a firebrake was cut. A bronze sword was found then. Further information revealed that trade was operated with the burial objects from this site. 1985 began trial excavations, which were continued in 1986. The excavations brought to light 34 tombs, which were partly destroyed and plundered. A part of the stolen goods was later found in the storehouse of the [[Archaeological Museum of Dion|Archaeological Museum in Dion]]. In 1985, some of the stone slabs that covered the tombs were stolen by unknown culprits. A part of the slope was brought to a drop by heavy snowfalls. In the years 1987 and 1988 the slope was terraced and stabilized by a wooden construction. Near the excavation site Spathes, 1987 more tombs were discovered, presumably from the same epoch. Six stone seals were recovered from them, further excavations were not held.<ref>Poulaki-Pandermali, Efi. ''Makedonikos Olympos''. Greek Ministry of Culture and Sport, 2013, page 56</ref><ref>Greek Ministry of Culture and Sport, Aristoteles University Thessaloniki, ''Το Αρχαιολογικό Έργο στή Μακεδονία και Θράκη ((The archeolgical work in Macedonia and Thrace) Nr. 1'', 1987, page 200</ref>
== Necropolis == As in this region of Greece, at the end of the Bronze Age, the deceased were usually buried in box-shaped tombs. The type of these tombs is known from southern Greece. The length of the tombs is approximately 2.40 meters, the width 1.50 meters and the depth between one and 2.50 meters. The bottom of the tombs was covered with a 10 to 20 centimeter high clay layer, the side walls were framed with stone slabs. The graves were intact except for penetrating roots and natural deposits of the building materials. The number of buried persons found in the intact tombs is 52. It is unusual that in each of the tombs several people were buried, presumably they were family tombs. They were buried next to each other, partly also upon one another; In addition to the skeletons of adults, the remains of children were also found.<ref>Poulaki-Pandermali, Efi. ''Makedonikos Olympos''. Greek Ministry of Culture and Sport, 2013, page 54</ref>
== Finds == [[File:Bronzenes Schwert.jpg|thumb|Bronzen Sword, found near Platamonas]] In addition to weapons and jewelry, the deceased was mainly given pottery. However, some of them were broken by the kind of burial of several people within the same tomb. The vessels were partly handmade, partly they were modeled with a potter's wheel. The most important finds were made in a tomb, in which apparently high ranking personalities were buried.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.academia.edu/2565519/Social_Status_as_Reflected_through_Metal_Objects_Found_in_Archaic_Burials_from_Macedonia|title=Social Status as Reflected through Metal Objects Found in Archaic Burials from Macedonia}}</ref> Two skeletons, one male and one female, found themselves alongside rich burial gifts. Remnants of a spear, a bronze sword, painted and unpainted vases and perfume bottles, jewelry and stone seals (partly with animal motifs) were discovered. The sword is somewhat smaller, but resembles in the kind of swords found in [[Mycenae]] and [[Crete]] ([[Knossos]], [[Heraklion]]). A bronze sword found in another tomb is of the same making as swords discovered in [[Athens]], Crete, [[Kos]] and other locations. Recently, excavations on the southeast side of Olympus, to the west of [[Platamonas]], have revealed an identical sword.

Mythos – Istoria – Archäologia.'' Hrsg.: Greek Ministry of Culture and Sport, Thessaloniki 2013, {{ISBN|978-960-386-110-2}}.
